quotes.topic_title: Leadership diagnosis: can’t, won’t, not set up
quotes.text: There are only three reasons why things do not happen the way you want them to happen as a leader.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Sets up a simple diagnostic framework leaders can use to quickly categorize execution failures.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership diagnosis: can’t, won’t, not set up
quotes.text: You can look at a person, and you would say either that person can't do, which is a capability issue, or they won't do, which is a motivation or an alignment issue, or they were not set up to do, which is really your problem that you didn't set up the ways of working now design properly.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Provides a memorable three-bucket model (can’t/won’t/not set up) that clarifies whether to address skills, incentives, or systems.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership diagnosis: can’t, won’t, not set up
quotes.text: So, as a leader, do you have the right people in terms of capability?
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Turns the framework into an actionable self-check for leaders before assuming execution issues are personal failings.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership diagnosis: can’t, won’t, not set up
quotes.text: If they won't do, why won't they?
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Emphasizes root-cause inquiry on motivation/alignment rather than defaulting to blame or performance management.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I've been looking to get more India-based product leaders on the podcast because this podcast has a large audience in India.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the importance of tailoring product conversations (and often product strategy) to the context and needs of a specific market segment.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When I put out a call on Twitter and LinkedIn asking people who I should have on, Anuj was the single most requested person.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of using lightweight audience research (social channels) to validate demand and prioritize who/what to invest in.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we dig into how product management is different in India, Anuj's lessons about building product experiences for new users, how he operationalized the working backwards process at the companies he's worked at, why he pushes his teams to explore three divergent directions before settling on a plan, why he thinks product managers and companies should be much more full stack than they are.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Previews several actionable methodologies—working backwards, exploring three divergent directions, and “full-stack” PM thinking—that practitioners can adopt.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So I think one part is just the tenure, and B, I think it's just a lot of people have known the work.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A simple mental model for reputation-building: longevity plus visible, recognized output.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We would go to the internet, and look at YouTube, and look at SVPG and all of that, but what we would understand would not... you could not put directly to the Indian startups.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A cautionary, actionable reminder that imported playbooks often need localization to your market and constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you think about a company, who is the VP of business, and who is the VP of supply, and sales, and ops, and technology, and all of that? That group knew how to work with each other to build software products. They understood how that would be built and what to expect.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Frames product success as an ecosystem capability (cross-functional operating model), not just strong PMs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What they would have seen in their journeys in terms of what we expect is a very request response kind of understanding which is, "Here's machinery. If I give this X resources, I expect, with a little bit of variability, why predictable output will come," and that mentality also moved on to what I expect from product managers or product building journeys and so on.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A vivid explanation of why stakeholders mismanage software teams: treating product like predictable manufacturing.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: All right. Now, I understand software is not machinery. Consumers are not predictable as much as we thought.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A memorable, counterintuitive shift that justifies experimentation, iteration, and probabilistic planning in product work.

quotes.topic_title: How product building differs in India
quotes.text: I think till about 2010-ish, there were not really many products built for the Indian consumers in the first place.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A concrete timeline marker that explains why India’s product ecosystem and PM craft had to develop later and differently.

quotes.topic_title: How product building differs in India
quotes.text: There was no playbooks, and so on, and so forth.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Highlights the need for first-principles thinking and local experimentation when established PM templates don’t exist.

quotes.topic_title: How product building differs in India
quotes.text: We would go to the internet, and look at YouTube, and look at SVPG and all of that, but what we would understand would not... you could not put directly to the Indian startups.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that importing “best practices” requires adaptation to local market realities rather than copy-paste execution.

quotes.topic_title: How product building differs in India
quotes.text: What they would have seen in their journeys in terms of what we expect is a very request response kind of understanding which is, "Here's machinery. If I give this X resources, I expect, with a little bit of variability, why predictable output will come," and that mentality also moved on to what I expect from product managers or product building journeys and so on.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A memorable mental model (“software is not machinery”) that explains misaligned expectations and why PM work is inherently probabilistic.

quotes.topic_title: How product building differs in India
quotes.text: All right. Now, I understand software is not machinery. Consumers are not predictable as much as we thought.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive shift for operators from traditional industries: outcomes aren’t deterministic, so iteration and learning must be built into planning.

quotes.topic_title: When India’s consumer internet really ramped
quotes.text: I think 2010 was when it started because... Look, there were a few products that were built before that also, and I think somebody said this clearly that usually, when modern consumer internet starts coming in countries, it usually starts with travel, so you do have... Basically, any country, we would start with, usually, the first travel company.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Offers a reusable mental model for identifying early consumer-internet category patterns when analyzing new markets.

quotes.topic_title: When India’s consumer internet really ramped
quotes.text: There were a few very interesting products being built in India which were solving uniquely for the Indian consumers that were in the matrimony side which is Shaadi.com, and Bharmatrimony.com, and so on.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Highlights that early breakout products can come from culturally specific problems rather than global “clone” categories.

quotes.topic_title: When India’s consumer internet really ramped
quotes.text: We're like, "What do you think about Tinder?" India is famous for arranged marriages, so a product that would really understand that, "Hey, if you're a parent, if you want to get your kid up for matrimony, how would you solve for them?" and that marketplace of matchmaking, et cetera started.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A concrete example of designing for the real user/job-to-be-done (parents) instead of importing a Western product archetype.

quotes.topic_title: When India’s consumer internet really ramped
quotes.text: Now, you see a whole bunch of startups which are trying to do not only things which are... what could an Uber for India look like or what could a DoorDash for India look like. Very different and also, very innovative.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Captures the shift from “X for India” cloning to India-first innovation as a product strategy lens.

quotes.topic_title: India’s scale, infrastructure, and complexity
quotes.text: From smartphones, there was what we call the Jio revolution. There's an Indian company called Reliance Jio that basically got internet at the cheapest prices for smartphones. So because of this, a whole population came onto the internet which was hungry for newer products, newer content, completely different ways of interacting with each other, and using internet for all sorts of different things.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Highlights how a step-change in access/pricing can create an entirely new user base with different behaviors—critical for product strategy and onboarding.

quotes.topic_title: India’s scale, infrastructure, and complexity
quotes.text: So even if 5 rupees, that is basically 10 cents or less than that, that would be paid through UPI, and people started moving away from cash and so on.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how low-friction payments enable micro-transactions, expanding what business models and UX flows are viable.

quotes.topic_title: India’s scale, infrastructure, and complexity
quotes.text: There's something called the India Stack that is all of these things coming together, which is social security, identity, payments, and so on, that a whole bunch of other apps can now use to build their own layers on top of that.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A reusable platform mental model: build on shared primitives (identity/payments) to accelerate product development and distribution.

quotes.topic_title: India’s scale, infrastructure, and complexity
quotes.text: There's an elders' quote in India like, "Every 15 miles, the language will change, and the people and the culture will change, and it's a huge country of so many people."
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for why localization and segmentation must be foundational, not an afterthought, in large diverse markets.

quotes.topic_title: India’s scale, infrastructure, and complexity
quotes.text: So while there's a lot of people who are going to give you traffic, and engagement, and so on, but the craft of actually choosing the right kind of paying customer who will actually come, and engage, and give you money is at a premium.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Counterintuitive monetization lesson: scale and engagement don’t guarantee revenue—pricing and customer selection become core product work.

quotes.topic_title: Designing for new users: lazy, vain, selfish
quotes.text: Whereas the reality is most consumers in the country or in your target market, they don't care, and they may have sometime heard about your product.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that teams overestimate user attention and familiarity, especially at the top of the funnel.

quotes.topic_title: Designing for new users: lazy, vain, selfish
quotes.text: So they are lazy, they are vain, and they're selfish.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A memorable framework for designing onboarding and first impressions around real user psychology.

quotes.topic_title: Designing for new users: lazy, vain, selfish
quotes.text: So lazy meaning, "I don't have time for this, so blow my mind away. Otherwise, I'm not going to pay attention."
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to optimize early UX for speed-to-value and immediate payoff.

quotes.topic_title: Designing for new users: lazy, vain, selfish
quotes.text: It's going to make the biggest amount of change in terms of a product success, then your core product features that you're going to build for your loyal consumers.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prioritization claim: onboarding and first impressions can matter more than advanced features.

quotes.topic_title: Designing for new users: lazy, vain, selfish
quotes.text: Most neglect it.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A pointed observation that many teams underinvest in onboarding craft despite acknowledging its importance.

quotes.topic_title: Applying onboarding insights at Swiggy and Jupiter
quotes.text: Instead of that, we just started reframing it from the point of view of, "What would you want, and how could you use us? What is it in it for you?" and we started connecting all our marketing messages along with the onboarding.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A practical reframing: design onboarding around the user’s desired outcome and ensure continuity from acquisition messaging into the product.

quotes.topic_title: Applying onboarding insights at Swiggy and Jupiter
quotes.text: So even going out market and thinking, "Where do you actually find us? How did you know about us? It's a reasonably large brand. Why have you not already downloaded us and used us? Have you used us and rejected us in the past?"
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A diagnostic set of questions to uncover real adoption triggers and past rejection reasons, not just optimize the in-app flow in isolation.

quotes.topic_title: Applying onboarding insights at Swiggy and Jupiter
quotes.text: So building that entire mental model and looking at a user from the point of view of, "Let's assume that you have heard about us 20 times. What was that exact situation that brought you to download this app?"
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for onboarding: assume repeated exposure and identify the specific moment/context that finally caused conversion.

quotes.topic_title: Applying onboarding insights at Swiggy and Jupiter
quotes.text: How do we continue that journey on your onboarding from your splash, that 200 rupees of... X rupees if you buy from us, continuing that entire journey in the language that they understand and with the user experience that is continuation from the marketing to product, other thing that we started focusing on a lot more, and it instantly started showing us results.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A concrete tactic: carry the exact promo/value prop and language from ads into the first session to create a seamless “marketing → product” experience.

quotes.topic_title: Applying onboarding insights at Swiggy and Jupiter
quotes.text: But when people think about why using us only for one service and just go away, actually, the key is to recognize that this user has found value in... They are not interested in all the other things that you talked about, so be able to empathize with that user, and now thinking about the behavioral science aspects in terms of, "How do I convert this user from one to the other?"
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A cross-sell/cross-pollination insight for multi-product apps: don’t pitch everything—start from the one value they already found and use behavioral design to move them to the next product.

quotes.topic_title: PMs as full-stack influencers (users and teams)
quotes.text: One of the reasons why I really feel product managers must, if not better, but equally understand, category consumers which are not in market or which are not really buying your products just yet. As good as the marketer or the brand expert in your team does...
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Highlights a practical shift in PM focus toward understanding non-users/adjacent users as deeply as marketing does to drive better positioning and onboarding.

quotes.topic_title: PMs as full-stack influencers (users and teams)
quotes.text: Over a period of time, what is the right time when I introduce them to this other one rather than being very greedy about letting the new user try everything?
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on sequencing/cross-sell timing—optimize for the right moment instead of overwhelming new users with everything at once.

quotes.topic_title: PMs as full-stack influencers (users and teams)
quotes.text: The other thing that I feel a lot of product managers don't do right is... "Forget about everything. Here's my app. Go figure," is how most of the products are designed unfortunately.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A memorable critique of common onboarding failures that pushes PMs to design guided, intentional user journeys rather than self-serve discovery.

quotes.topic_title: PMs as full-stack influencers (users and teams)
quotes.text: We are product managers, and we are in the business of influence.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A crisp mental model reframing the PM role around influencing stakeholders and user behavior, not just building features.

quotes.topic_title: PMs as full-stack influencers (users and teams)
quotes.text: So you are a full-stack influencer and not only an external influencer. So we've got to think more like sales, more like marketing, more like influencers.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Extends the influence model into a concrete operating stance—PMs should borrow tactics from sales/marketing to drive adoption and alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing Working Backwards with PR/FAQ
quotes.text: My insight or at least the way that I thought about this one is it's not working backwards only from a customer value proposition.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Reframes “working backwards” as broader than customer value, setting up a more operational, end-to-end approach.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing Working Backwards with PR/FAQ
quotes.text: but essentially, what you're working backwards from is an entire machinery at a particular day that is working for... For the date of GTM, what do we need to do from here till that particular day so that the GTM is successful, but also, what will be the machinery we would have created so that this product is successful?
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Defines a practical mental model: plan backwards from a fully functioning go-to-market “machine,” not just a feature launch.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing Working Backwards with PR/FAQ
quotes.text: You can use it for negotiation, for example, because you start with a date, and then you say, "This is the one-pager that I need to ship, and I want the consumers to see that."
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Shows how PR/FAQ becomes a concrete negotiation artifact anchored on a ship date and customer-facing promise.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing Working Backwards with PR/FAQ
quotes.text: We can also use the quotes here to actually find alliances or find people who are going to actually derail this.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Highlights a tactical use of stakeholder/customer quotes to surface misalignment and political risk early.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing Working Backwards with PR/FAQ
quotes.text: So I actually ask my teams to write three press releases, alternative and divergent like, "What if we..."
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Introduces an actionable “power of three” method to force divergent thinking and improve leadership decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Power of three: write three divergent PR/FAQs
quotes.text: So I actually ask my teams to write three press releases, alternative and divergent like, "What if we..."
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A concrete discovery tactic: force teams to explore multiple divergent solutions before committing.

quotes.topic_title: Power of three: write three divergent PR/FAQs
quotes.text: within these three, and they all need to be fully thought-through, and that helps the leadership choose.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Emphasizes that alternatives must be complete enough to enable real tradeoff decisions by leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Power of three: write three divergent PR/FAQs
quotes.text: But when you're doing this three PR FAQs, I considered this, and this added up to a story that eventually is valuable, this alternative route.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Shows how three PR/FAQs can make stakeholder input feel heard by documenting considered paths, not just the chosen one.

quotes.topic_title: Power of three: write three divergent PR/FAQs
quotes.text: That, actually, is a very powerful tool even for CXOs. When they say, "Let's build this," you'll say, "Here are three ways we can build this, and here's the reason why I'm not building what you said because you would like these two more."
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive way to handle top-down directives: respond with structured options and rationale rather than a yes/no.

quotes.topic_title: Using FAQs to manage marketplace complexity
quotes.text: So the FAQs also are very important to set processes in the system.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Frames FAQs as an operational mechanism to bake repeatable decision-making and governance into product development.

quotes.topic_title: Using FAQs to manage marketplace complexity
quotes.text: So every FAQ will mandatorily have, "How are you going to make sure that it is fully compliant? Have you gotten sign-off from A, B, C people? Have you actually thought about legal aspects, and so on, and so forth?"
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A concrete example of using mandatory FAQ prompts to enforce compliance and cross-functional sign-offs in regulated products.

quotes.topic_title: Using FAQs to manage marketplace complexity
quotes.text: Now, any small change that you do on, say, delivery partners, for example, if you're working on optimizing their earnings per hour which will lead to some changes in cost per delivery, but that may have a completely different impact on delivery fee.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Illustrates second-order effects in a three-sided marketplace where optimizing one side can unintentionally shift outcomes elsewhere.

quotes.topic_title: Using FAQs to manage marketplace complexity
quotes.text: I'm just making this up, but now, because of so many moving parts in your FAQs, you're explicitly asking, "Have you thought about what are the implications on restaurant partners? Have you thought about what are implications on delivery partners?"
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Shows how structured FAQ questions force teams to evaluate multi-sided impacts before shipping changes.

quotes.topic_title: Using FAQs to manage marketplace complexity
quotes.text: It gets everybody together to create very crisp products that work for all sides of the marketplace.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Captures the coordination benefit of FAQs as a tool to align stakeholders across interconnected marketplace participants.

quotes.topic_title: Why full-stack PMs win: outcomes over features
quotes.text: I think product managers have to own outcomes and not only features and parts of the problem.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A clear north star for PMs: measure success by outcomes, not by shipping features or owning a narrow slice.

quotes.topic_title: Why full-stack PMs win: outcomes over features
quotes.text: Did it work in the way that it really changed the behavior of the kind of user that we wanted to achieve a business outcome that will build a capability that is important for us?
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A practical test for success that ties product work to behavior change, business outcomes, and capability building.

quotes.topic_title: Why full-stack PMs win: outcomes over features
quotes.text: So they have to think about external users, they have to think about competition, they have to think about other product managers and product leaders about engineering, about marketing, and so on because it's such a diverse field.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Defines the “full-stack PM” scope as cross-functional and market-aware, not just feature execution.

quotes.topic_title: Why full-stack PMs win: outcomes over features
quotes.text: Either you are very, very good at that, or you have built partnerships, and have run your ideas or product through those people and gotten weighted from them, and finally made a decision around that part, I don't think you'll be very successful.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: you don’t need to be the expert in every domain, but you must build strong partnerships and incorporate their input into decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Why full-stack PMs win: outcomes over features
quotes.text: So, in my opinion, the full-stack product managers are the ones who are going to be more successful rather than product managers who are doing very good at one particular area only.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A contrarian stance against narrow specialization: breadth and end-to-end ownership are positioned as the winning strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Show don’t tell: person-based journeys and walls
quotes.text: There's a concept of person, not personas.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that pushes teams to model a real, specific individual rather than an abstract persona.

quotes.topic_title: Show don’t tell: person-based journeys and walls
quotes.text: We try to recreate an exact situation.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to ground product ideation in concrete, realistic scenarios instead of assumptions.

quotes.topic_title: Show don’t tell: person-based journeys and walls
quotes.text: So you literally start from there, and I think 50% of my product reviews are on that part, and then when we say, "All right. Then, this app got open. Do we have the right kind of way forward for Lenny to actually achieve what he came here for?" Literally, each pixel, and each copy, and each word is going to be in service of that part.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A concrete review methodology: start from the trigger and ensure every UI/detail serves the user’s goal.

quotes.topic_title: Show don’t tell: person-based journeys and walls
quotes.text: What is happening? What's the emotional state of the user, and let's plot out the 30 minutes time, and let's create various scenarios.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A practical framework for marketplaces: map real-time dynamics and user emotions across the full waiting/fulfillment window.

quotes.topic_title: Show don’t tell: person-based journeys and walls
quotes.text: I think I recommend this every product manager to do a show don't tell version of their current version. At the same time, there's a new version all the time. So they can compare and contrast, and very easily explain to everyone why they're doing something.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A repeatable practice: maintain current vs. future journey artifacts to drive clarity and stakeholder alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of show don’t tell: alignment and decisions
quotes.text: So I think the largest impact that the show don't tell has is on, basically, getting the entire company together on the same page and them being able to understand why I'm doing, and which part of the entire picture I am working on, and why others are working on so that I can actually work with them to solve that part.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Highlights the core benefit of concrete artifacts: cross-functional alignment around the full system, not isolated workstreams.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of show don’t tell: alignment and decisions
quotes.text: The other thing that it helps, Lenny, is it also helps in choosing directions, like I said, because we are not doing one, but three of them.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Shows a practical decision-making use case: comparing multiple strategic alternatives side-by-side rather than debating abstractly.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of show don’t tell: alignment and decisions
quotes.text: and sometimes these strategic discussions, they can get going all sorts of different ways, and maybe you will talk about one particular unique point and go deeper rather than look at the entire picture together and say, "This is good because of all of these five points that we presented in page one versus the other one."
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: A counter to common strategy debates: force holistic evaluation criteria instead of getting stuck on one deep rabbit hole.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of show don’t tell: alignment and decisions
quotes.text: I think the other benefit, just one of the benefits of working backwards in Amazon's whole written-down memo approach is it forces you to crystallize ideas and not stay superficial because there's so many good ideas in theory.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Captures the “working backwards” methodology as a mechanism to turn vague ideas into testable specifics.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of show don’t tell: alignment and decisions
quotes.text: But then, when you have to get really concrete, that's actually a terrible idea.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Memorable heuristic: specificity is a filter that exposes weak ideas early.

quotes.topic_title: Four BB framework for product strategy allocation
quotes.text: So I don't think it's a tactical prioritization product manager call. It really is a product strategy call, and the conversation that needs to happen is between, say, the head of product and the CEO or even the leadership.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Reframes prioritization as an explicit leadership-level strategy tradeoff rather than a PM-level backlog exercise.

quotes.topic_title: Four BB framework for product strategy allocation
quotes.text: If I gave you a hundred focus points, how much will you put in each of these buckets, and what are those four buckets? Those are the four BB buckets, so what are the ones? We call them... First BB is Brilliant Basics.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Introduces a capacity allocation method (“100 focus points”) and the Four BB buckets as a portfolio framework.

quotes.topic_title: Four BB framework for product strategy allocation
quotes.text: The reason why we call it BB, Brilliant Basic, you need to brand... You cannot brand it as tech debt, so it feels like very off because these are brilliant, these are important.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Actionable advice on positioning foundational work so it gets prioritized and supported, not dismissed as “tech debt.”

quotes.topic_title: Four BB framework for product strategy allocation
quotes.text: Breaking Bad essentially is a different world altogether. That's where you want to redefine your company.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Defines the “Breaking Bad” bucket as identity-shift work (pivots/repositioning), distinct from incremental improvements or big initiatives.

quotes.topic_title: Four BB framework for product strategy allocation
quotes.text: For example, in Swiggy, if we were doing food delivery, now we want to do grocery delivery as well. It's like these are two companies working together, or from a food delivery company, we wanted to become a convenience company. So that's almost breaking bad.
quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.context: Concrete example of what qualifies as “Breaking Bad”: expanding from a single product category into a broader company identity.
